articles.headline: After the Bank Failure Comes the Debt Collector
articles.snippet: Some small-business owners are in peril of foreclosure after their loans, once held by banks that have since failed, were bought by junk-loan buyers intent on collecting either the cash or the collateral.
articles.abstract: Some small-business owners are in peril of foreclosure after their loans, once held by banks that have since failed, were bought by junk-loan buyers intent on collecting either the cash or the collateral.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Rick Williamson, a Chicago banker turned junk-loan buyer, knew the name-calling would start again when he moved to foreclose on the Fayetteville Athletic Club, a sprawling, family-run gym and spa complex in this corner of northwest Arkansas.

articles.headline: Interrogation Memos Detail Harsh Tactics by the C.I.A.
articles.snippet: As the White House released secret memos describing interrogation techniques, it said it would not prosecute those who carried out the practices.
articles.abstract: As the White House released secret memos describing interrogation techniques, it said it would not prosecute those who carried out the practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Thursday made public detailed memos describing brutal interrogation techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency, as President Obama sought to reassure the agency that the C.I.A. operatives involved would not be prosecuted.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: A.I.G. Chief Owns Significant Stake in Goldman
articles.snippet: Although paid just $1 a year to lead A.I.G., Edward Liddy owns a large stake in Goldman Sachs, which was aided by the U.S. bailout of the struggling insurer.
articles.abstract: Although paid just $1 a year to lead A.I.G., Edward Liddy owns a large stake in Goldman Sachs, which was aided by the U.S. bailout of the struggling insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward M. Liddy, the dollar-a-year chief executive leading the American International Group since its bailout last fall, still owns a significant stake in Goldman Sachs, one of the insurer’s trading partners that was made whole by the government bailout of A.I.G.

articles.headline: Taliban Exploit Class Rifts in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The militants have organized landless tenants against wealthy landlords in a strategy that poses broad dangers for Pakistan.
articles.abstract: The militants have organized landless tenants against wealthy landlords in a strategy that poses broad dangers for Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — The Taliban have advanced deeper into Pakistan by engineering a class revolt that exploits profound fissures between a small group of wealthy landlords and their landless tenants, according to government officials and analysts here.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: To Fill Food Safety Gap, Processors Pay Inspectors
articles.snippet: Safety scares prompted California’s so-called leafy greens industry to pay for inspections that the F.D.A. rarely does.
articles.abstract: Safety scares prompted California’s so-called leafy greens industry to pay for inspections that the F.D.A. rarely does.
articles.lead_paragraph: HURON, Calif.  Clipboard in hand, Debra Anderson spent three hours one recent sunny morning trooping through a field of romaine lettuce looking for trouble.

articles.headline: Deal Brings TV Shows and Movies to YouTube
articles.snippet: In another step to become a destination for mainstream TV programs and movies, YouTube said it had signed deals with Hollywood studios to showcase their content.
articles.abstract: In another step to become a destination for mainstream TV programs and movies, YouTube said it had signed deals with Hollywood studios to showcase their content.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another step in its transformation from an online jumble of amateur videos to a destination for mainstream TV programs and movies, YouTube said Thursday that it had signed deals with Hollywood studios to showcase thousands of TV episodes and hundreds of movies on its Web site.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Dimming the Aura of Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: The investment bank denies that it profited from the U.S. bailout of A.I.G., but some of the public gets a sour taste.
articles.abstract: The investment bank denies that it profited from the U.S. bailout of A.I.G., but some of the public gets a sour taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be the most respected investment bank in the world. Now it seems to be a part of more conspiracy theories than the Central Intelligence Agency.

articles.headline: Heavy Debt Bankrupts Mall Owner
articles.snippet: General Growth’s bankruptcy was widely expected, but it underscored what many see as a looming crisis in commercial real estate.
articles.abstract: General Growth’s bankruptcy was widely expected, but it underscored what many see as a looming crisis in commercial real estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifty-five years ago, Martin and Matthew Bucksbaum built one of the nation’s first shopping centers, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Soon they built another, and another, and another  transforming their family company, now known as General Growth Properties, into a colossus of the American mall.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Terry Pristin

articles.headline: A Quick Bankruptcy for G.M.? Not So Fast
articles.snippet: Because of workers, bondholders and others who would want a hearing at a General Motors bankruptcy, the proceedings could take months.
articles.abstract: Because of workers, bondholders and others who would want a hearing at a General Motors bankruptcy, the proceedings could take months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any hope of a high-speed bankruptcy by General Motors faces a serious obstacle: a judge  not the Obama administration, not G.M. management and not the company’s creditors  would reign in court.

articles.headline: After Year of Heavy Losses, Citigroup Finds a Profit
articles.snippet: The bank’s reported income of $1.6 billion was helped by an accounting adjustment that allowed a one-time gain of $2.5 billion on its derivative positions.
articles.abstract: The bank’s reported income of $1.6 billion was helped by an accounting adjustment that allowed a one-time gain of $2.5 billion on its derivative positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than a year of crippling losses and three bailouts from Washington, Citigroup, a troubled giant of American banking, said Friday that it had done something extraordinary: it made money.

articles.headline: Lightweight Armor Is Slow to Reach Troops
articles.snippet: An experiment to shave up to 20 pounds off a soldier’s load has stalled, leaving equipment sitting in Virginia instead of being sent to Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: An experiment to shave up to 20 pounds off a soldier’s load has stalled, leaving equipment sitting in Virginia instead of being sent to Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Army has promised to lighten the soldier’s load, and nowhere more urgently than in eastern Afghanistan, where the unforgiving terrain tests the stamina of troops whose weapons, body armor, rucksacks and survival gear can weigh 130 pounds.
